issues.text: What do the words 'as it may judge' in section 18 mean? Do they confer on the Court of Wards a power to be exercised if the act is, in its judgment, for the benefit of the property or the advantage of the ward, or do they confer a power to be exercised only if, in fact, the act is for the benefit of the property or the advantage of the ward?

anchor.surface_text: It can be attacked on the ground that the Court of Wards did not act bona fide and in the interests of the ward, and that its action amounted to a fraud on the power. holdings.text: The words 'as it may judge' in section 18 confer on the Court of Wards a power exercisable based on its subjective judgment that the act is for the benefit of the property or advantage of the ward, not requiring that it be so in fact.

anchor.surface_text: Examining the language of section 18 in the light of these observations, we are unable to construe the words as it may judge most for the benefit of the property and the advantage of the ward as equivalent to as may be for the benefit of the property and the advantage of the ward or as might be judged to be most for the benefit of the property and the advantage of the ward. The statute confides in clear and unambiguous terms the authority to judge whether the act is beneficial to the estate, to the Court of Wards and not to any outside authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.18; distinguished from objective phrases; relied on Liversidge v. Anderson; statute unambiguously confides judgment to Court of Wards.

holdings.text: Exercise of power under s.18 can be impugned only for lack of bona fides (fraud on power) or non-application of mind; not for error on merits if honest judgment reached.

anchor.surface_text: That being the true scope of the power conferred by section 18, what are the grounds on which the exercise of such a power could be impugned in a court of law? It can be attacked on the ground that the Court of Wards did not act bona fide and in the interests of the ward, and that its action amounted to a fraud on the power. It can also be attacked on the ground that the Court of Wards did not, in fact, apply its mind to the question whether the act was for the benefit of the property or the advantage of the ward,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Followed principles from Allcroft v. Bishop of London; honest judgment not reviewable on merits unless failure amounts to no judgment.

holdings.text: Deed dated 26-3-1915 valid; Court of Wards applied mind to cess clause, which accords with statutory sharing under Bengal Cess Act ss.80-81; no exemption inferred under strict construction.

anchor.surface_text: As we have held that the Court of Wards did apply its mind to the question and formed its own judgment on it, its decision is not open to question, and the attack on the deed dated 26-3-1915 must in consequence fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of scrutiny (drafts, endorsements, Board sanction); strict construction against tax exemption (Mahanand Sahai); no pleading or evidence of negligence.

holdings.text: Court of Wards has power under s.18 to enter transactions binding post-majority of ward; no limitation tied to minority like in Guardians Act.

anchor.surface_text: There is no provision in the statute such as there is in section 29 b of the Guardians and Wards Act VIII of 1890 that a lease by the Court of Wards was to enure for a period related to the minority of the ward. Such a limitation cannot be read into section 18 for the obvious reason that the wards whose estates are to be administered under the Act, may, under section 6 of the Act, be females including majors declared incompetent to manage the properties or lunatics or persons who themselves apply that their estates might be taken over by the Court of Wards.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.18 general/unqualified; s.6 includes non-minors; duty to manage till charge ends; contrasted with Guardians Act.

holdings.text: In granting deed dated 23-11-1917, Court of Wards considered benefit to estate/ward, not only to licensees; applied mind to relevant aspects.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this evidence, it is impossible to contend that in entering into the transaction dated 23-11-1917, the Court of Wards had failed to consider the interests of the estate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Correspondence shows consideration of estate benefits (long-term exploitation, war conditions, alternatives); public interest secondary.

holdings.text: Deed dated 23-11-1917 validly sanctioned under s.18 by Board's letter dated 9-10-1917 approving essential terms; general prior sanction to transaction sufficient, no need for final document.

anchor.surface_text: We should accordingly construe the letter dated 9-10-1917 as sufficient sanction under section 18. The learned Judges of the High Court were of the opinion that Rule 242 framed under section 70 of the Act required that the sanction should be recited in the deed,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Followed Gulabsingh v. Gokuldas, Ramkanai v. Mathewson; s.18 sanctions transaction essentials; Rule 242 inapplicable to agreements.

holdings.text: Invalid clause in leases dated 2-8-1937 (postponing minimum royalty per void 1-6-1937 deed) severable; does not invalidate entire leases.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that a clause in a deed is not binding on the ground that it is unauthorised cannot ipso facto render the whole deed void, unless it forms such an integral part of the transaction as to render it impossible to sever the good from the bad.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Doctrine of severability; clause not integral; s.18 sanction to transaction independent of merits.

holdings.text: Deeds dated 26-3-1915 and 23-11-1917 valid and binding; leases granted pursuant thereto valid (except specified clause); specific performance decreed.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the deeds dated 26-3-1915 and 23-11-1917 are valid but not the deed dated 1-6-1937, and that the leases granted to the appellant are valid, but the clause postponing the payment of minimum royalty in the lease deed or deeds of 2-8-1937 is inoperative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of above holdings to facts; restores trial court decree.

precedents.citation: Nakkuda Ali v-. M. F. De. S. Jayaratne 1

anchor.surface_text: Nakkuda Ali v-. M. F. De. S. Jayaratne 1 . There, the Board was companysidering the meaning of the words where the Controller has reasonable grounds to believe occurring in a Regulation of Ceylon.

precedents.case_name: Nakkuda Ali v M F De S Jayaratne
precedents.cited_proposition: Meaning of words 'where the Controller has reasonable grounds to believe' in a regulation requires objective reasonable grounds, not mere subjective satisfaction.

anchor.surface_text: the decision in Liversidge v.Sir John Anderson 2  was relied on as establishing that position. In negativing this companytention, Lord Radcliffe observed that the words where the Controller had reasonable grounds to believe might mean either where it is made out to his subjective satisfaction or where there are reasonable grounds on which be companyld believe, and that whether the words were

precedents.cited_proposition: Words like 'reasonable cause to believe' can be subjective satisfaction.

anchor.surface_text: In Liversidge v. Sir John Anderson 1 , Lord Atkin who held that the words of Regulation 18-B of the Defence Regulations 1939 that if the Secretary of State has reasonable cause to believe meant if, in fact, there was reasonable cause for the belief, discussed what words were susceptible of importing an objective standard as companytrasted with subjective satisfaction, and observed It is surely incapable of dispute that the words if A has X companystitute a companydition the essence of which is the existence of X and the having of it by A.

precedents.cited_proposition: Words like 'if A has X' import objective existence of X, not subjective thought.
precedents.cited_holding: It is surely incapable of dispute that the words if A has X constitute a condition the essence of which is the existence of X and the having of it by A.

precedents.citation: Allcroft v. Lord Bishop of London Lighton v. Lord Bishop of London 1

anchor.surface_text: Allcroft v. Lord Bishop of London Lighton v. Lord Bishop of London 1 . There, the statute provided for certain action being taken unless the Bishop shall be of opinion that proceedings shall number be taken. Acting under this section the Bishop of London decided number to take proceedings, and the companyrectness of this decision was challenged in an application for mandamus.

precedents.case_name: Allcroft v Lord Bishop of London
precedents.cited_proposition: Court cannot interfere with honest exercise of judgment by statutory authority even if erroneous or incomplete consideration.
precedents.cited_holding: If a man is to form an opinion, and his opinion is to govern, he must form it himself on such reasons and grounds as seem good to him.

anchor.surface_text: Ashutosh Dhar v. Amir Mollah 1  and Mahanand Sahai v. Mussmat Sayedunissa Bibi 2  in support of this position. There, the question related to section 41 of the Act but it is argued that the principle underlying those decisions is equally applicable to section 81 and that, in our opinion, is companyrect.

precedents.cited_proposition: Parties can contract out of statutory liability for cess under Bengal Cess Act.

precedents.citation: Mahanand Sahai v. Mussmat Sayedunissa Bibi 2

anchor.surface_text: and Mahanand Sahai v. Mussmat Sayedunissa Bibi 2  in support of this position. There, the question related to section 41 of the Act but it is argued that the principle underlying those decisions is equally applicable to section 81 and that, in our opinion, is companyrect. The next step in the argument is that the cess clause in the Bokaro license embodies a companytract modifying the rights declared by section 81 of the Act by throwing the liability for the cess wholly on the tenant but that the clause in the 1915 deed restricts it to the obligation as declared in section 81 and has therein resulted in serious disadvantage to the proprietor.

precedents.case_name: Mahanand Sahai v Mussmat Sayedunissa Bibi
precedents.cited_proposition: Parties can contract out of statutory liability for cess under Bengal Cess Act.

precedents.citation: Mahanand Sahai v. Mussmat Sayedunissa Bibi 1

anchor.surface_text: Mahanand Sahai v. Mussmat Sayedunissa Bibi 1  It is indisputable that when an exemption is claimed from statutory liability, the companytract under which exemption is claimed, must be strictly companystrued against the claimant and it must appear from its terms, beyond the possibility of any dispute, that the parties intended to vary the liability as imposed by the statute.

precedents.case_name: Mahanand Sahai v Mussmat Sayedunissa Bibi
precedents.cited_proposition: Strict construction against exemption from statutory tax liability; must clearly show intention to vary statute.
precedents.cited_holding: It is indisputable that when an exemption is claimed from statutory liability, the contract under which exemption is claimed, must be strictly construed against the claimant and it must appear from its terms, beyond the possibility of any dispute, that the parties intended to vary the liability as imposed by the statute.

anchor.surface_text: and this view has been adopted in Balwantrao Naik v. Biswanath Missir 2  and Ramkumari Devi v. Hari Das 3 . The companytention of the appellant, therefore, that the cess clause in the Bokaro license cannot be companystrued as a clear expression of an intention on the part of the parties to companytract themselves out of the statute is number without force.

precedents.cited_proposition: Adopts strict construction for cess exemption clauses.

anchor.surface_text: Balwantrao Naik v. Biswanath Missir 2  and Ramkumari Devi v. Hari Das 3 . The companytention of the appellant, therefore, that the cess clause in the Bokaro license cannot be companystrued as a clear expression of an intention on the part of the parties to companytract themselves out of the statute is number without force. It is, however, unnecessary to decide this question, as assuming that the cess clause in the deed dated 26-3-1915 is less advantageous to the ward than that in the Bokaro license, the respondent has, before he can succeed on this companytention, still to establish that the Court of Wards did number apply its mind to this matter.

precedents.cited_proposition: Adopts strict construction for cess exemption clauses.

anchor.surface_text: The decision in Gulabsingh v. Seth Gokuldas 1  was relied on in support of this position. There, the Deputy Commissioner had sent to the Commissioner a proposal to borrow Rs. 1,00,000 from the plaintiffs firm, and on 28th January 1891 the Commissioner was informed by the secretariat that the Chief Commissioner had accepted the proposals for the liquidation of the debt.

anchor.surface_text: t was erroneous or that be had number companysidered all the aspects of the matter. The following observations of Lord Bramwell may be quoted Then it

anchor.surface_text: Examining the language of section 18 in the light of these observations, we are unable to construe the words as it may judge most for the benefit of the property and the advantage of the ward as equivalent to as may be for the benefit of the property and the advantage of the ward or as might be judged to be most for the benefit of the property and the advantage of the ward. The statute confides in clear and unambiguous terms the authority to judge whether the act is beneficial to the estate, to the Court of Wards and not to any outside authority.
The appeals must accordingly be allowed, the decrees of the companyrt below set aside, and these of the trial companyrt restored.

anchor.surface_text: earing on the question whether the proceedings should be allowed to go on. That being so, it is number for your Lordships, on this application for a m

anchor.surface_text: That being the true scope of the power conferred by section 18, what are the grounds on which the exercise of such a power could be impugned in a court of law? It can be attacked on the ground that the Court of Wards did not act bona fide and in the interests of the ward, and that its action amounted to a fraud on the power. It can also be attacked on the ground that the Court of Wards did not, in fact, apply its mind to the question whether the act was for the benefit of the property or the advantage of the ward,
The appeals must accordingly be allowed, the decrees of the companyrt below set aside, and these of the trial companyrt restored.

anchor.surface_text: As we have held that the Court of Wards did apply its mind to the question and formed its own judgment on it, its decision is not open to question, and the attack on the deed dated 26-3-1915 must in consequence fail.
The appeals must accordingly be allowed, the decrees of the companyrt below set aside, and these of the trial companyrt restored.
has therein resulted in serious disadvantage to the proprietor. For the appellant, it is companytended that the clause in the Bokaro license companyld

anchor.surface_text: There is no provision in the statute such as there is in section 29 b of the Guardians and Wards Act VIII of 1890 that a lease by the Court of Wards was to enure for a period related to the minority of the ward. Such a limitation cannot be read into section 18 for the obvious reason that the wards whose estates are to be administered under the Act, may, under section 6 of the Act, be females including majors declared incompetent to manage the properties or lunatics or persons who themselves apply that their estates might be taken over by the Court of Wards.
The appeals must accordingly be allowed, the decrees of the companyrt below set aside, and these of the trial companyrt restored.

The appeals must accordingly be allowed, the decrees of the companyrt below set aside, and these of the trial companyrt restored.
